data.title: Fix 3D Box blending with textures with fully transparent pixels
data.body: Use the OpenGL alpha testing to discard the drawing of fully transparent pixels of 3D box textures. However, this method doesn't work for semi-transparent pixels that would require a manual ordering of box sides combined with some advanced rendering method.

data.title: For each and JS events are not gray when disabled
data.body:
The conditions/actions in the "for each" are but it's not consistent not to have the event "header" grayed.

JS events are not grayed when disabled (and maybe the C++ events to).

data.title: Fix error description in variable.js
data.body:
fix error description at line 94 to 100.
Before the description in the same as 77 to 83

data.title: [js] runtimeobjects without RendererObject throw exceptions when updating their z-order
data.body:
As the z-order is called at the beginning for each created objects, it makes the game freeze at 100%.

The bug happens with objects without RendererObject (runtimeobject.getRendererObject() not redefined). This is the case for the text entry object.

Possible fix, add a if(object.getRendererObject()) in gdjs.RuntimeObject.prototype.setZOrder to surround the z-order update in the layer.

@victorlevasseur I had error while compiling on OS X with the new FileStream and I think you forgot to fix a constructor.
With this PR it seems to work properly (I can compile, open a game, export it, not tested much more). Can you tell me if this looks good to you? I'll merge it then. :)

data.title: Translation and formatting expressions
data.body:
**Native game only implementation**
**Do not merge now, opened for discussions.**

This PR adds two features.

# The features
## String formatting

A string expression provides a **string formatting feature** with a simple and easier syntax than the C syntax.

For example:
```
Format("{0} is {2} but the parser still need some {1}", "Formatting", "work!", "cool")
```

I implemented a small parser for this syntax, tell me how I can improve/optimize it. It uses ```std::string```
 internally to avoid unnecessary UTF8 iterating as the only relevant characters are {, } and the numbers.

To make this string expression possible, I added a new type to the parameters: ````variadic```. The kind of parameter obviously only works if placed at the end of an expression/action/condition parameters list. The extraInfo field is used to determine the type of the variadic parameter (only one type, either "string" or "expression", so this is more limited than the C++ parameters packs). 

These parameters accepts from 0 to an infinity of values. **The editors have not been updated to allow assisted insertion of such parameters making them impossible to use currently in conditions and actions. However, the expression parser has been updated not to throw error messages due to the parameter count with variadics.**

## Translation

Using the ```_("something here")``` string expression, strings can be translated. A button has been added to the "Project" ribbon to generate a .pot file from all marked strings and an action is provided to load a translation from a .mo file.

The .mo parsing is done with a simple "parser" I wrote too.

Here is the documentation draft of the translation feature: http://wiki.compilgames.net/doku.php/gdevelop/documentation/game_translation

# Discussion

**Some points I would like to discuss:**

 - this: #318 
 - The formatting parser is working but I think it can be largely optimized, ideas ?
 - Javascript implementation
 - GUI for variadic parameters in expressions editors
 - GUI for variadic parameters in instruction editor
 - Allowing (in the conventional way) .mo files to be added in the project resources ("Image bank").

data.title: ExpressionParser in external events
data.body:
I wonder if it's possible to use ExpressionParser with an external event (or nothing) instead of a ```gd::Layout```.

What I want to do is to write a custom callback to get all the _(...) string expressions from the expressions/strings from all the events of a project. I already browse the whole project by using a ```ArbitraryEventWorker``` on all the scene's events and external events. But, then, I would like to fetch all the _(...) expressions from the expressions of the actions/conditions/variable child name... I currently use a regex thanks to wxWidgets but I would like to use a more appropriate solution.

*You can guess what I'm doing :p, and it already works on the ```feature/string-format``` branch of my fork (the branch is named after the first feature that I added to the branch.*

data.title: gd::FileStream is slow
data.body: Probably introduced by #312. But still surprising because I remember having fixed a bug causing that prior to merge the PR. It still seems that gd::FileStream fails closing preventing a further ```open``` call on the same stream, especially on Windows.

data.title: Custom fonts crashes with gd::SFMLFileStream
data.body: Because the stream should be kept alive while the sf::Font is used (it's a streaming object).

data.title: Bugfix/particle system
data.body:
By using ```sf::Texture::getNativeHandle()```.

However, it needs SFML 2.3 at least, so I've updated SFML to 2.4.1. SFML is now embedded into the repository so it's more easier to track its updates (we are sure that everybody has the good SFML version and it's also easier for build workers as they wouldn't have been able to update SFML by themselves).

*In fact, I've been building GDevelop with SFML 2.3.1 for months on my computer, that's why I first fixed the bug by use a SFML >= 2.3 feature).*

data.title: Time scale for layers
data.body:
This refactor objects and layers to add custom time scale support for layers.
In particular `UpdateTime`/`updateTime` has been renamed `Update`/`update`. The whole scene is passed as an argument, avoiding some objects to retain a pointer to the scene which was hacky.
Runtime objects have a `GetElapsedTime` that is used to get the elapsed time for the object (that depends on the scene time scale and layer time scale).
A test game is included.

Actions/conditions/expressions are available to change the time scale for a layer (native and JS game engine support). 

This enables to "pause" the gameplay of a layer while still having other layers animations running (for example, an interface or a tutorial with animations displayed while the game is paused).

data.title: Introduce gd::FileStream
data.body:
What is this new class ?
===
This class is an equivalent of ```std::fstream``` (and can also replace ```std::[io]fstream```) but it allows to load a file from a path as a ```gd::String```.

On Linux/Mac OS, this is a simple wrapper:
```c++
gd::String filepath = "some weird characters here.txt";

//You can do this:
gd::FileStream f(filepath); // or f.open(filepath);
//Instead of:
std::fstream f(filepath.ToLocale());
```

Why ?
===
But, the class is the most useful on Windows as the libstd implementation of ```std::[io]?fstream``` is only able to open file with an ASCII filename (no support for ```std::wstring``` filepaths).

On Windows, ```gd::FileStream``` can open a file with **non ASCII filepaths** (given that the path is still obviously supported by Windows itself and its weird ~~UTF-16~~ UCS-2 encoding)

How ?
===
```gd::FileStream``` uses a MinGW extension that allows to open a file from a C ```FILE*``` descriptor. Luckily enough, MinGW provides a Microsoft extension that allows to open a C ```FILE*``` descriptor from a wide path (```wchar_t*```). The class manages the file descriptor and a filebuffer that makes the link between the ```std::iostream``` (```gd::FileStream``` as ```std::fstream``` inherits from ```iostream```).

On Linux, the class directly opens a ```std::filebuf``` and link it to the base ```std::iostream```. As the filesystem encoding is considered to follow the locale, the ```gd::String``` is converted into the current locale (often ```UTF-8``` these days) before opening the file.

Tests
===

Tests have been added to test the critical parts of the class (the browsing, reading, writing operations are managed by the ```std::iostream```` so no need to test them. Only the opening/closing and states are tested).

Bonus Nb.1
===

This PR also implements a ```gd::SFMLFileStream``` that allows SFML resources can be loaded from files like this:

```cpp
gd::SFMLFileStream stream;
stream.open("aaaa.png");

sf::Texture texture;
 texture.loadFromStream(stream);
```

Bonus Nb.2
===

It also provides two functions, one to load a ```TiXmlDocument``` from a file with ```gd::String``` and one to save it to a file.

data.title: Automatic versioning
data.body: Get the GDevelop version from git and set it inside a Version header which is updated each time the version described by git is different.

data.title: ImageManager::GetOpenGlTexture doesn't work properly
data.body:
This method is only used by the ParticleSystem (the 3D box binds the sf::Texture directly) and it seems that the texture is not properly created (it is created as a mono-color square).

Two ways to fix it:
 - Fix the method itself
 - Use sf::Texture::getNativeHandle with the ParticleSystem to use a sf::Texture with the particles and delete the GetOpenGlTexture. However, it needs to update SFML to 2.3 at least.

data.title: Rethinking GDevelop versioning and release process
data.body:
I think that the long delay between the stable updates of GDevelop is really long because of the way we manage them.

We should aim towards a more semantic versioning management: we used to increment the revision number for each version, the minor number for "almost big changes or not so big new features" and the major number for "big changes".

I suggest we change to this: for a given version X.Y.0
 - Fix bugs in versions X.Y.Z, Z > 0
 - Begin to work on and merge **new features** for the version X.(Y+1).0 (on a separate branch).

This way, we can release fixed version much quicker (not a lot of test required).
